intro: Amomum crassilabium, commonly known as the broad-lipped cardamom, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of Southeast Asia. It belongs to the ginger family (Zingiberaceae) and is characterized by its tall, erect stems and broad, lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces fragrant, pale yellow flowers arranged in dense inflorescences, which are followed by spherical, three-lobed fruits. Its rhizomes are often harvested for their aromatic compounds, which are used in traditional medicine and as a spice. Amomum crassilabium thrives in humid, shaded environments and is often found in tropical and subtropical forests.
